mn63:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn63:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn63:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmato mālukyaputtassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
mn63:2.1.eng: Then as Venerable Māluṅkyaputta was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:
mn63:2.1.comm: Māluṅkyaputta was, according to Pali commentaries, the son of the lady Māluṅkyā of Kosala. Alternatively, Sanskrit dictionaries give māluka as the name of a people or a mixed caste, although I have not been able to trace any further details. His conversion is not recorded as he appears always as a monk in Pali. This discourse and MN 64 depict him as somewhat of a fool, but it seems that he persisted, and late in life sought teachings in meditation and ultimately realized arahantship, of which we have two different accounts (AN 4.257, SN 35.95). The latter contains an extensive set of verses attributed to him, which are repeated at Thag 16.5. A second set of his verses are at Thag 6.5.

mn63:2.2.eng: “There are several convictions that the Buddha has left undeclared; he has set them aside and turned them down.

mn63:2.3.pli: ‘sassato loko’tipi, ‘asassato loko’tipi, ‘antavā loko’tipi, ‘anantavā loko’tipi, ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīran’tipi, ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīran’tipi, ‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi, ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi—
mn63:2.3.eng: For example: the cosmos is eternal, or not eternal, or finite, or infinite; the soul and the body are one and the same, or the soul is one thing, the body another; after death, a realized one still exists, or no longer exists, or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists.

mn63:2.4.eng: The Buddha does not explain these points to me.

mn63:2.5.pli: Yāni me bhagavā na byākaroti taṃ me na ruccati, taṃ me nakkhamati.
mn63:2.5.eng: I don’t endorse that, and do not accept it.

mn63:2.6.eng: I’ll go to him and ask him about this.

mn63:2.7.eng: If he gives me a straight answer on any of these points,

mn63:2.9.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā—

mn63:2.10.eng: I will lead the spiritual life under him.

mn63:2.11.eng: If he does not explain these points to me,

mn63:2.13.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā—

mn63:2.14.eng: I shall disavow the training and return to a lesser life.”

mn63:3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mālukyaputto sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā mālukyaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn63:3.1.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Māluṅkyaputta came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and told the Buddha of his thoughts. He then continued:

mn63:3.2.pli: “Idha mayhaṃ, bhante, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi—

mn63:3.3.pli: yānimāni diṭṭhigatāni bhagavatā abyākatāni ṭhapitāni paṭikkhittāni:

mn63:3.5.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’tipi—

mn63:3.7.pli: Yāni me bhagavā na byākaroti taṃ me na ruccati, taṃ me nakkhamati.

mn63:3.11.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā—

mn63:3.15.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā—

mn63:3.18.eng: that the cosmos is eternal, please tell me.

mn63:3.20.eng: that the cosmos is not eternal, tell me.

mn63:3.22.pli: ‘sassato loko’ti vā, ‘asassato loko’ti vā, ajānato kho pana apassato etadeva ujukaṃ hoti yadidaṃ:
mn63:3.22.eng: whether the cosmos is eternal or not, then it is straightforward to simply say:

mn63:3.29.pli: ‘antavā loko’ti vā, ‘anantavā loko’ti vā, ajānato kho pana apassato etadeva ujukaṃ hoti yadidaṃ:

mn63:3.32.pli: ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīran’ti, ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīran’ti me bhagavā byākarotu;
mn63:3.32.eng: that the soul and the body are one and the same,

mn63:3.34.pli: ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīran’ti, ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīran’ti me bhagavā byākarotu.
mn63:3.34.eng: or is the soul one thing, the body another;

mn63:3.36.pli: ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīran’ti vā, ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīran’ti vā, ajānato kho pana apassato etadeva ujukaṃ hoti yadidaṃ:

mn63:3.39.pli: ‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, ‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti me bhagavā byākarotu;
mn63:3.39.eng: that after death, a realized one still exists,

mn63:3.41.pli: ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti me bhagavā byākarotu.

mn63:3.43.pli: ‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ajānato kho pana apassato etadeva ujukaṃ hoti yadidaṃ:

mn63:3.46.pli: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti me bhagavā byākarotu;
mn63:3.46.eng: or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists, please tell me.

mn63:3.48.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti me bhagavā byākarotu.

mn63:3.50.pli: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ajānato kho pana apassato etadeva ujukaṃ hoti yadidaṃ:
mn63:3.50.eng: any of these things, then it is straightforward to simply say:

mn63:4.1.eng: “What, Māluṅkyaputta, did I ever say to you:

mn63:4.2.pli: ‘ehi tvaṃ, mālukyaputta, mayi brahmacariyaṃ cara, ahaṃ te byākarissāmi:
mn63:4.2.eng: ‘Come, Māluṅkyaputta, lead the spiritual life under me, and I will declare these things to you’?”

mn63:4.3.pli: “sassato loko”ti vā, “asassato loko”ti vā, “antavā loko”ti vā, “anantavā loko”ti vā, “taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīran”ti vā, “aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīran”ti vā, “hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā, “na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā, “hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā, “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā’”ti?

mn63:4.5.eng: “Or did you ever say to me:

mn63:4.6.pli: ‘ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ carissāmi, bhagavā me byākarissati:
mn63:4.6.eng: ‘Sir, I will lead the spiritual life under the Buddha, and the Buddha will declare these things to me’?”

mn63:4.7.pli: “sassato loko”ti vā, “asassato loko”ti vā, “antavā loko”ti vā, “anantavā loko”ti vā, “taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīran”ti vā, “aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīran”ti vā, “hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā, “na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā, “hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā, “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā’”ti?

mn63:4.9.eng: “So it seems that I did not say to you:

mn63:4.10.pli: ‘ehi tvaṃ, mālukyaputta, mayi brahmacariyaṃ cara, ahaṃ te byākarissāmi:
mn63:4.10.eng: ‘Come, Māluṅkyaputta, lead the spiritual life under me, and I will declare these things to you.’

mn63:4.12.pli: “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā”’ti;

mn63:4.13.eng: And you never said to me:

mn63:4.14.pli: ‘ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ carissāmi, bhagavā me byākarissati:
mn63:4.14.eng: ‘Sir, I will lead the spiritual life under the Buddha, and the Buddha will declare these things to me.’

mn63:4.16.pli: “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā’ti.

mn63:4.17.pli: Evaṃ sante, moghapurisa, ko santo kaṃ paccācikkhasi?
mn63:4.17.eng: In that case, you futile man, who are you and what do you want to disavow?

mn63:5.1.eng: Suppose someone were to say this:

mn63:5.2.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ carissāmi yāva me bhagavā na byākarissati:
mn63:5.2.eng: ‘I will not lead the spiritual life under the Buddha until the Buddha declares to me

mn63:5.3.eng: that the cosmos is eternal, or that the cosmos is not eternal …

mn63:5.4.pli: “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā’ti,
mn63:5.4.eng: or that after death a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists.’

mn63:5.5.pli: abyākatameva taṃ, mālukyaputta, tathāgatena assa, atha so puggalo kālaṃ kareyya.
mn63:5.5.eng: That would still remain undeclared by the Realized One, and meanwhile that individual would die.

mn63:5.6.pli: Seyyathāpi, mālukyaputta, puriso sallena viddho assa savisena gāḷhapalepanena.
mn63:5.6.eng: Suppose a man was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison.

mn63:5.7.pli: Tassa mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā bhisakkaṃ sallakattaṃ upaṭṭhapeyyuṃ.
mn63:5.7.eng: His friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat him.

mn63:5.9.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ purisaṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, khattiyo vā brāhmaṇo vā vesso vā suddo vā’ti;
mn63:5.9.eng: ‘I won’t extract this arrow as long as I don’t know whether the man who wounded me was an aristocrat, a brahmin, a peasant, or a menial.’
mn63:5.9.comm: “Extract this arrow”(imaṁ sallaṁ āharissāmi): in his Ayurvedic text Aṣṭāṅgahṛdayasaṁhitā, Vāgbhaṭa devotes the entirety of chapter 1.28 to this procedure (śalyāharaṇavidhi).

mn63:5.11.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ purisaṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto iti vā’ti;
mn63:5.11.eng: ‘I won’t extract this arrow as long as I don’t know the following things about the man who wounded me: his name and clan;

mn63:5.13.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ purisaṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, dīgho vā rasso vā majjhimo vā’ti;
mn63:5.13.eng: whether he’s tall, short, or medium;

mn63:5.15.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ purisaṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, kāḷo vā sāmo vā maṅguracchavī vā’ti;
mn63:5.15.eng: whether his skin is black, brown, or dingy;

mn63:5.17.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ purisaṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, amukasmiṃ gāme vā nigame vā nagare vā’ti;
mn63:5.17.eng: and what village, town, or city he comes from.

mn63:5.19.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ dhanuṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, yadi vā cāpo yadi vā kodaṇḍo’ti;
mn63:5.19.eng: I won’t extract this arrow as long as I don’t know whether the bow that wounded me was straight or recurved;
mn63:5.19.comm: It would appear that dhanu is the general word for “bow”, of which cāpa and kodaṇḍa are specialized varieties. These bows appear with others in a list of weapons at Arthaśāstra 2.18.8. While it is not clear what these were exactly, kodaṇḍa is sometimes used for “eyebrows”, suggesting that the bow of that name was of the recurve type favored by horsemen, and the cāpa by contrast may have been straight.

mn63:5.21.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ jiyaṃ jānāmi yāyamhi viddho, yadi vā akkassa yadi vā saṇhassa yadi vā nhārussa yadi vā maruvāya yadi vā khīrapaṇṇino’ti;
mn63:5.21.eng: whether the bow-string is made of swallow-wort fibre, sunn hemp fibre, sinew, sanseveria fibre, or spurge fibre;
mn63:5.21.comm: The identifications for these are from Ñāṇatusita’s notes to Bodhi’s translation.

mn63:5.23.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ kaṇḍaṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, yadi vā gacchaṃ yadi vā ropiman’ti;
mn63:5.23.eng: whether the shaft is made from a bush or a plantation tree;

mn63:5.25.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ kaṇḍaṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, yassa pattehi vājitaṃ yadi vā gijjhassa yadi vā kaṅkassa yadi vā kulalassa yadi vā morassa yadi vā sithilahanuno’ti;
mn63:5.25.eng: whether the shaft was fitted with feathers from a vulture, a heron, a hawk, a peacock, or a stork;

mn63:5.27.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ kaṇḍaṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, yassa nhārunā parikkhittaṃ yadi vā gavassa yadi vā mahiṃsassa yadi vā bheravassa yadi vā semhārassā’ti;
mn63:5.27.eng: whether the shaft was bound with sinews of a cow, a buffalo, a black lion, or an ape;
mn63:5.27.comm: The animals bherava (“terrifier”, variant roruva “roarer”) and semhāra are otherwise unknown. The commentary explains them as “black lion” and “monkey”.

mn63:5.29.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ sallaṃ āharissāmi yāva na taṃ sallaṃ jānāmi yenamhi viddho, yadi vā sallaṃ yadi vā khurappaṃ yadi vā vekaṇḍaṃ yadi vā nārācaṃ yadi vā vacchadantaṃ yadi vā karavīrapattan’ti—
mn63:5.29.eng: and whether the arrowhead was spiked, razor-tipped, barbed, made of iron or a calf’s tooth, or lancet-shaped.’
mn63:5.29.comm: Again from Ñāṇatusita. Note that calves lose their teeth, and the roots are evidently quite sharp.

mn63:5.30.pli: aññātameva taṃ, mālukyaputta, tena purisena assa, atha so puriso kālaṃ kareyya.
mn63:5.30.eng: That man would still not have learned these things, and meanwhile they’d die.

mn63:5.31.pli: Evameva kho, mālukyaputta, yo evaṃ vadeyya:
mn63:5.31.eng: In the same way, suppose someone was to say:

mn63:5.32.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ carissāmi yāva me bhagavā na byākarissati:
mn63:5.32.eng: ‘I will not lead the spiritual life under the Buddha until the Buddha declares to me

mn63:5.33.eng: that the cosmos is eternal, or that the cosmos is not eternal …

mn63:5.34.pli: “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti vā’ti—
mn63:5.34.eng: or that after death a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists.’

mn63:5.35.pli: abyākatameva taṃ, mālukyaputta, tathāgatena assa, atha so puggalo kālaṃ kareyya.
mn63:5.35.eng: That would still remain undeclared by the Realized One, and meanwhile that individual would die.

mn63:6.1.pli: ‘Sassato loko’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evaṃ no.
mn63:6.1.eng: It’s not true that if there were the view ‘the cosmos is eternal’ there would be the living of the spiritual life.
mn63:6.1.comm: This is a double conditional, the sense being that if the pre-condition is met (locative absolute), the subsequent act would follow (conditional). The form echoes Māluṅkyaputta’s conditions, which is why the syntax here is more convoluted than in similar cases elsewhere.

mn63:6.2.pli: ‘Asassato loko’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evampi no.
mn63:6.2.eng: It’s not true that if there were the view ‘the cosmos is not eternal’ there would be the living of the spiritual life.

mn63:6.3.pli: ‘Sassato loko’ti vā, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati, ‘asassato loko’ti vā diṭṭhiyā sati attheva jāti, atthi jarā, atthi maraṇaṃ, santi sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā;
mn63:6.3.eng: When there is the view that the cosmos is eternal or that the cosmos is not eternal, there is rebirth, there is old age, there is death, and there is sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

mn63:6.4.eng: And it is the defeat of these things in this very life that I advocate.

mn63:6.5.pli: ‘Antavā loko’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evaṃ no.
mn63:6.5.eng: It’s not true that if there were the view ‘the cosmos is finite’ …

mn63:6.6.pli: ‘Anantavā loko’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evampi no.

mn63:6.7.pli: ‘Antavā loko’ti vā, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati, ‘anantavā loko’ti vā diṭṭhiyā sati attheva jāti, atthi jarā, atthi maraṇaṃ, santi sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā;

mn63:6.9.pli: ‘Taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīran’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evaṃ no.
mn63:6.9.eng: ‘the soul and the body are one and the same’ …

mn63:6.10.pli: ‘Aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīran’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evampi no.
mn63:6.10.eng: ‘the soul is one thing, the body another’ …

mn63:6.11.pli: ‘Taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīran’ti vā, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati, ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīran’ti vā diṭṭhiyā sati attheva jāti …pe…

mn63:6.13.pli: ‘Hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evaṃ no.
mn63:6.13.eng: ‘a realized one still exists after death’ …

mn63:6.14.pli: ‘Na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evampi no.
mn63:6.14.eng: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death’ …

mn63:6.15.pli: ‘Hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā diṭṭhiyā sati attheva jāti …pe…

mn63:6.17.pli: ‘Hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evaṃ no.
mn63:6.17.eng: ‘a realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death’ …

mn63:6.18.pli: ‘Neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati brahmacariyavāso abhavissāti, evampi no.
mn63:6.18.eng: ‘a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death’ there would be the living of the spiritual life.

mn63:6.19.pli: ‘Hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā diṭṭhiyā sati attheva jāti …pe…
mn63:6.19.eng: When there are any of these views there is rebirth, there is old age, there is death, and there is sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

mn63:6.20.eng: And it is the defeat of these things in this very life that I advocate.

mn63:7.1.pli: Tasmātiha, mālukyaputta, abyākatañca me abyākatato dhāretha;
mn63:7.1.eng: So, Māluṅkyaputta, you should remember what I have not declared as undeclared,

mn63:7.2.eng: and what I have declared as declared.

mn63:7.3.eng: And what have I not declared?

mn63:7.4.eng: I have not declared the following: ‘the cosmos is eternal,’

mn63:7.11.eng: ‘the soul and the body are one and the same,’

mn63:7.13.eng: ‘the soul is one thing, the body another,’

mn63:7.15.eng: ‘a realized one still exists after death,’

mn63:7.17.eng: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death,’

mn63:7.19.pli: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti—
mn63:7.19.eng: ‘a realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death,’

mn63:7.21.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti—
mn63:7.21.eng: ‘a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death.’

mn63:8.1.eng: And why haven’t I declared these things?

mn63:8.2.pli: Na hetaṃ, mālukyaputta, atthasaṃhitaṃ na ādibrahmacariyakaṃ na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattati.
mn63:8.2.eng: Because they aren’t beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

mn63:8.3.eng: That’s why I haven’t declared them.

mn63:9.2.eng: I have declared the following: ‘this is suffering,’

mn63:9.7.eng: ‘this is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

mn63:10.1.eng: And why have I declared these things?

mn63:10.2.pli: Etañhi, mālukyaputta, atthasaṃhitaṃ etaṃ ādibrahmacariyakaṃ nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati.
mn63:10.2.eng: Because they are beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

mn63:10.3.eng: That’s why I have declared them.

mn63:10.4.pli: Tasmātiha, mālukyaputta, abyākatañca me abyākatato dhāretha;
mn63:10.4.eng: So, Māluṅkyaputta, you should remember what I have not declared as undeclared,

mn63:10.5.eng: and what I have declared as declared.”

mn63:10.6.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn63:10.7.pli: Attamano āyasmā mālukyaputto bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mn63:10.7.eng: Satisfied, Venerable Māluṅkyaputta approved what the Buddha said.
